newsitem.title: USA: Perot rebuffed in U.S. court to get into debates.
newsitem.headline: Perot rebuffed in U.S. court to get into debates.

text.p: Presidential candidate Ross Perot failed in a federal court challenge on Tuesday to get included in televised presidential debates between President Bill Clinton and Republican challenger Bob Dole.

U.S. District Judge Thomas Hogan rejected a request by the Reform Party leader for a restraining order to prohibit the debates unless he was a participant in the two encounters, the first scheduled for this Sunday in Hartford, Connecticut.
The ruling also applied to another minor party candidate, John Hagelin of the Natural Law Party, who had also sought a court ruling to stop the debates unless he was included.
Jamin Raskin, one of Perot's lawyers, said there would be an appeal to the U.S. District Court of Appeals.

The second presidential debate is scheduled for Oct. 16 in San Diego and a vice presidential debate between Vice President Al Gore and Republican Jack Kemp is due to be held in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Oct. 9.

Raskin and lawyers for Perot and Hagelin argued that the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates violated Federal Election Commission rules that sponors of debates must use "objective" criteria to select debaters.
They said their candidates qualified under objective criteria used by the debate commission which has been making recommendations for presidential debates since 1988.
Among the criteria were that candidates should be on enough state ballots to be able to win the necessary 270 electoral votes to become president.

The lawyers for Perot and Hagelin argued that the debate commission had used "subjective" criteria in deciding that only Clinton and Dole had "a realistic chance" of getting elected in the Nov 5 race.

Perot's legal team argued that the debate commission consulted "pollsters and pundits" in interviews to decide whether Perot had a realistic chance of winning and decided he did not in violation of his rights.
Perot's lawyer argued that rules of the Federal Election Commission had been violated and rules of that commission and the debate commission were unconstitutional.
Lewis Loss, a lawyer for the bipartisan debate commission, argued that the commission had no powers to force anyone to debate even if Hogan said Perot and Hagelin should debate.
A ruling requiring Perot or Hagelin to debate would threaten the debates taking place at all, Loss said.

He said an order from the court affecting the debates "poses a substantial risk that there would be no debates." Loss argued that both Clinton and Dole were "skittish" anyway about debating in the first place.

Negotiators for Clinton and Dole agreed with the commission's recommendation for only Clinton-Dole debates although Clinton had preferred that Perot be included, while Dole opposed Perot's inclusion for fear he could take votes away from him.
